title: 109_s477
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tribal Government Amendments to the Homeland Security Act of 2002". Congress recognizes the government-to-government relationship between the United States and Indian tribal governments, acknowledging their inherent sovereignty, self-determination, and self-governance rights. Each tribal government has the authority to establish its own form of government, adopt a constitution, establish a tribal judicial system, and provide for the health and safety of residents on tribal lands, including law enforcement services. Tribal emergency response providers, including law enforcement officers and medical personnel, are crucial for the health and safety of residents on tribal lands. Over 25 Indian tribes have jurisdiction over lands near the Canadian or Mexican border. The involvement of tribal governments in protecting the homeland of the United States is crucial for comprehensive homeland security. Tribal lands near the Canadian or Mexican border provide direct access to the United States by boat. Indian tribal governments have jurisdiction over lands with important resources like dams, oil and gas deposits, and power plants. The Act aims to ensure that the Department of Homeland Security collaborates with Indian tribal governments to protect the homeland of the United States. It emphasizes the full participation of tribal governments in homeland security efforts. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to update the table of contents by removing section 801. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a new section on the Office of State, Tribal, and Local Government Coordination. Definitions in the Act are updated to include the term "Indian tribe" as any organized group eligible for special programs and services in the continental United States. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include definitions for "tribal college or university" and "tribal government" in relation to Indian tribes recognized by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to provide funds directly to eligible Indian tribes, bands, nations, or organized groups in the continental United States for special programs and services.
